In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the solution:
```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    if typeof(dt) == Date
        throw(ArgumentError("The function only works with DateTime type, not Date"))
    end
    
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end
```
This function takes a DateTime object and an optional `bump` argument (defaulting to 3 hours if no value is provided). If the input is of type Date instead of DateTime, it throws an error. Otherwise, it adds the bump amount of hours to the DateTime object and returns the new DateTime object.
